title: New research suggests the Moon is much older than previously believed - The Jerusalem Post
summary:
New Research Suggests the Moon is Much Older Than Previously Believed

Publication Date: DECEMBER 19, 2024

Source: The Jerusalem Post

The research, published in the journal Nature, reveals that the Moon may have formed up to 4.51 billion years ago, over 80 million years earlier than earlier estimates. This could change understanding of lunar history and geology.

  • The Moon's age has been recalculated based on crystalline inclusions found in rock samples.
  • Previous lunar age estimates derived from Apollo mission samples suggested a cooling age of 4.35 billion years.
  • The Moon's formation is linked to a collision between Earth and a Mars-sized body named Theia.
  • Gravitational interactions have caused dynamic changes in the Moon's orbit and heating of its crust.
  • The study indicates that the Moon's surface age reflects a remelting event rather than its original formation.
"The Moon 'would seem to have formed very late, 200 million years after the beginning of the solar system...'" - Alessandro Morbidelli, co-author of the study.

China's upcoming Chang'e 6 mission aims to return samples from the far side of the Moon, which could provide further insights into its true age.
newTitle: New Research Suggests the Moon is Much Older Than Previously Believed

title: Insights From The First Global Appraisal Of Microbiomes In Earth’s Subsurface Environments - Astrobiology News
summary:
Insights From The First Global Appraisal Of Microbiomes In Earth’s Subsurface Environments

Date: December 2024

Source: Astrobiology

This groundbreaking study at the Marine Biological Laboratory reveals significant microbial diversity in Earth's subsurface environments, challenging assumptions about microbial survival and energy availability.

  • First global study of microbial diversity in subsurface environments, revealing high diversity up to 491 meters below the seafloor.
  • Study highlights the potential for bioprospecting new compounds from these ecosystems.
  • Contrasts marine and terrestrial microbiomes, showing different compositions but similar levels of diversity.
  • Research suggests that subsurface microbes may have incredibly long generation times, reflecting different ecological adaptations.
  • Findings could inform the search for extraterrestrial life, particularly on Mars where similar conditions may exist.
“We can now also appreciate that perhaps half the microbial diversity on Earth is in the subsurface.” - Emil Ruff

This study unveils the vast unexplored diversity within Earth's subsurface, opening new avenues for research in microbiology and astrobiology.
newTitle: Insights From The First Global Appraisal Of Microbiomes In Earth’s Subsurface Environments

title: Breathtaking images of astronauts in space captured by NASA - India.com
summary:
Breathtaking images of astronauts in space captured by NASA

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India.com

This article showcases stunning images of NASA astronauts engaging in various activities aboard the International Space Station, capturing moments of their scientific work and daily life in space.

  • NASA astronauts Loral O’Hara and Tracy C. Dyson review documents in the ISS.
  • Satoshi Furukawa sets up a video camera for a physics experiment.
  • Andreas Mogensen jogs on a treadmill inside the ISS.
  • NASA astronauts take photographs of Earth from the ISS cupola.
  • Astronauts wear eye-protecting specs during a solar eclipse.
“Thanks For Reading!”

This collection of images highlights the remarkable work and unique experiences of astronauts in space, emphasizing their contributions to science and exploration.
newTitle: Breathtaking images of astronauts in space captured by NASA

title: Cosmic holiday wonders: Star clusters shine like wreaths and Christmas trees - News Karnataka
What the world can see from China’s record-breaking spacewalk: Global Times editorial - Global Times
Webb offers best glimpse ever into icy planetesimals of early solar system - Phys.org
Scientists Are Stunned by Juno’s Groundbreaking Discovery Beneath Io’s Volcanic Surface - The Daily Galaxy --Great Discoveries Channel
summary:
Scientists Are Stunned by Juno’s Groundbreaking Discovery Beneath Io’s Volcanic Surface

Publication Date: 2024-02-25 Source: NASA

Navigating close to Io, Juno's recent flybys revealed that the moon's volcanic eruptions are driven by localized magma chambers rather than a global magma ocean.

  • Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system, featuring over 400 active volcanoes.
  • Juno's close flybys in late 2023 and early 2024 allowed scientists to gather precise gravitational data.
  • The study found that Io's tectonic activity is significantly influenced by tidal flexing from its orbit around Jupiter.
  • Local magma chambers are the source of its eruptions, challenging previous theories of a vast magma ocean.
  • The findings have implications for understanding other celestial bodies, including Europa and Enceladus.
“Since Morabito’s discovery, planetary scientists have wondered how the volcanoes were fed from the lava underneath the surface.” - Scott Bolton

This discovery not only clarifies Io's volcanic mechanics but also shapes future planetary exploration strategies.
newTitle: Juno Unveils Surprising Insights Into Io's Volcanic Activity

title: New Study Reveals Incredible Microbial Life Deep Under Earth’s Surface - Gadgets 360
summary:
New Study Reveals Incredible Microbial Life Deep Under Earth’s Surface

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Science Advances

A landmark global study has unveiled extraordinary microbial diversity thriving deep below Earth's surface. Conducted by a team led by Emil Ruff at the Marine Biological Laboratory, the research provides insights into life forms existing at depths up to 4,375 metres underground.

  • The study highlights the richness of microbial life in subsurface ecosystems, rivaling surface biodiversity.
  • It showcases a comparison of microbial diversity between marine and terrestrial ecosystems, revealing unique community compositions.
  • Reports suggest that 50-80% of Earth's microbial cells live in subsurface environments, some dividing very infrequently.
  • The implications for extraterrestrial life research were discussed, drawing parallels between Earth's and Mars' subsurface ecosystems.
  • The research was credited for its uniform methodology, enhancing data comparisons across a wide range of samples.
“Certain subsurface habitats surpass surface ecosystems in diversity.” - Emil Ruff

This study opens new avenues for understanding microbial life in extreme conditions and its implications for both Earth and extraterrestrial environments.
newTitle: New Study Reveals Incredible Microbial Life Deep Under Earth’s Surface

title: Chiron's Unique Surface and Coma: Key Insights from Recent Space Research - Gadgets 360
summary:
Chiron's Unique Surface and Coma: Key Insights from Recent Space Research

Publication Date: [Date Not Provided] | Source: Gadgets 360

Researchers have examined (2060) Chiron, a celestial body orbiting between Jupiter and Neptune, revealing its unusual surface and gaseous composition. According to a study published in Astronomy & Astrophysics, Chiron displays characteristics of both asteroids and comets, classifying it as a centaur.

  • Chiron shows signs of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide ice on its surface.
  • It has methane and carbon dioxide gases present in its coma.
  • The research can provide insights on the solar system's origins.
  • Follow-up studies are planned as Chiron approaches the Sun.
Dr. Noemí Pinilla-Alonso, an Associate Scientist, stated that Chiron's coma allows researchers to study gases from beneath the surface, which is rare in other celestial bodies.

Understanding Chiron could reveal important information about the processes that shape many small bodies in the solar system.
newTitle: Chiron's Unique Surface and Coma: Key Insights from Recent Space Research

title: Updated World Magnetic Model Predicts Magnetic North Pole’s Shift - Gadgets 360
summary:
Magnetic North Pole shift triggers new World Magnetic Model

Date: December 17, 2023 | Source: Gadgets 360

The National Centers for Environmental Information and the British Geological Survey have released an updated version of the World Magnetic Model to enhance navigational accuracy due to shifts in the magnetic North Pole.

  • The updated WMM forecasts changes in Earth's magnetic field over the next five years.
  • It is critical for maintaining the reliability of navigational systems, including satellite and smartphone navigation.
  • The magnetic North Pole is moving due to fluid dynamics in Earth's outer core.
  • The update integrates data from the European Space Agency's Swarm mission.
“The model allows navigation tools to provide reliable directions by accounting for fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field.” - William Brown, BGS

This updated model is expected to sustain navigational reliability, ensuring accuracy without noticeable changes for most users.
newTitle: Magnetic North Pole Shift Leads to Updated World Magnetic Model

title: How the axolotl rose from obscurity to global stardom - The Economist
summary:
How the Axolotl Rose from Obscurity to Global Stardom

Date: Dec 19th 2024 | Source: Mexico City

The axolotl, a remarkable amphibian, has transitioned from relative obscurity to a beloved global figure, intertwining with culture and nature in significant ways.

  • The axolotl is celebrated for its unique regenerative abilities.
  • It has cultural significance in Mexico, linking back to the Aztecs.
  • Its popularity soared due to its portrayal in media and art, including Pokémon.
  • Conservation efforts are crucial as the species faces threats in its natural habitat.
“The quiet network of waterways was built by the Aztecs long before the Spanish conquest.”

This journey of the axolotl highlights the intersection of conservation, culture, and global fascination, urging further protection efforts for such unique species.
newTitle: How the Axolotl Became a Global Phenomenon

title: This baby exoplanet is made of different stuff than its birth cloud - Space.com
summary:
This Baby Exoplanet is Made of Different Stuff Than Its Birth Cloud

Publication Date: December 18, 2023 | Source: Space.com

Astronomers have discovered that planets can significantly differ from the gas and dust from which they are born, challenging the prevailing model of planet formation. This finding came from a study of PDS 70b, a gas giant discovered in the protoplanetary disk surrounding its star.

  • The study was led by Northwestern University researchers.
  • PDS 70b is three times the mass and diameter of Jupiter and is located 369 light-years away.
  • Scientists expected the carbon and oxygen ratios in the planet's atmosphere to match those in the protoplanetary disk, but found them to be much lower.
  • The findings suggest that the accepted model of planet formation may be overly simplistic.
  • Future research will focus on PDS 70c, a companion planet to PDS 70b.
“For observational astrophysicists, one widely accepted picture of planet formation was likely too simplified,” said Chih-Chun “Dino” Hsu of Northwestern University.

In conclusion, the discovery of PDS 70b's unique composition prompts a reevaluation of the models that explain how planets form from their natal materials.
newTitle: This Baby Exoplanet is Made of Different Stuff Than Its Birth Cloud

title: Around the World in 365 Days - Payload
summary:
Around the World in 365 Days

Date: December 17, 2024Source: Payload Space

This article discusses the latest developments in international collaborations and advancements in space exploration, detailing significant news stories related to space initiatives.

  • Europe's plans for the IRIS2 constellation to strengthen its space autonomy.

  • The Artemis Accords celebrating 50 signatories, expanding international participation in lunar exploration.
  • ICEYE's alliance with Space42 to enhance the UAE's space industry.

title: 7 pictures from space that show how Earth changed in 2024 - India Today
summary:
7 Pictures from Space Showing Earth's Changes in 2024

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: India Today

This article showcases how Earth's landscape has changed significantly in 2024 through stunning images captured from space.

  • Cyclone Chido, a Category 4 storm, struck Mayotte with 225 km/h winds, causing severe damage.
  • Record-breaking heat in the Northern Hemisphere led to multiple deaths and power strain during summer 2024.
  • Astronauts captured images of Turkmenistan's unique geography, including its dunes and oil industry.
  • The San Juan Islands are highlighted for their geology and fossil-rich marine state park.
  • Japan's autumn hues were delayed due to above-average heat.
  • Australia's Willandra region showcases historical megafauna remains amidst its landscapes.
  • A photograph focuses on the illuminated towns of Namibia and South Africa and how they are affected by desert and industry.
“Cyclone Chido devastated Mayotte with 225 km/h winds caused widespread damage.”
“Record-breaking heatwaves caused deaths and extreme temperatures across many cities.”

The images and stories presented highlight the urgent and ongoing changes on our planet, reflecting both the beauty and challenges faced by Earth in 2024.
newTitle: 7 Pictures from Space Showing Earth's Changes in 2024

title: Harnessing the Power of Light for Efficient Water Splitting - AZoM
summary:
Harnessing the Power of Light for Efficient Water Splitting

Date: (2024), Source: Chem Catalysis

Researchers from the Institute of Science Tokyo, led by Assistant Professor Megumi Okazaki, have identified key factors affecting water-splitting efficiency in a study published in Chem Catalysis. The study examines the roles of pH levels, metal oxide (MOx) catalysts, and Ru(II) photosensitizers.

  • Studied water oxidation using light for sustainable energy.
  • Key findings on pH levels influence on water-splitting efficiency.
  • Introduced a method for estimating catalyst performance.
  • Explored unique onset pH conditions for different MOx catalysts.
  • Highlights the importance of adjusting reaction potential.
  • Objectives include enhancing clean energy technologies.

Reaction potential (EMOx) plays a critical role in the water oxidation process...

— Megumi Okazaki, Assistant Professor, Institute of Science Tokyo

The findings show how modifying pH and reaction potential can enhance the efficiency of water oxidation, paving the way for a shift to renewable energy technologies.
newTitle: Harnessing the Power of Light for Efficient Water Splitting

title: Shenzhou-19 crew performs longest spacewalk in China's history - TV BRICS (Eng)
Massive 120-foot asteroid set to flyby Earth at high speed just a day before Christmas, NASA alerts - Moneycontrol
Early universe’s monstruous black hole caught in a post-meal nap - Tech Explorist
summary:
Early Universe's Monstrous Black Hole Caught in a Post-Meal Nap

Publication Date: 2024 | Source: Tech Explorist

A team of astronomers using the James Webb Space Telescope made an extraordinary discovery. They detected a massive black hole in the early universe that appears to be “napping” after eating too much food.

  • This black hole, about 800 million years after the Big Bang, is 400 million times the mass of our Sun.
  • It is located in the host galaxy JADES GN+189.09144+62.22811 1001830.
  • The black hole constitutes about 40% of the mass of its galaxy.
  • Its growth has slowed considerably, accreting gas at only 1/100th of the expected speed.
  • The discovery suggests that black holes may experience short periods of ultra-fast growth followed by long dormancy.
“It’s possible that black holes are born big or grow in a series of hyperactive bursts followed by extended periods of napping.” - Professor Roberto Maiolino

Understanding this black hole may shed light on the formation and growth of black holes in the early universe.
newTitle: Early Universe's Monstrous Black Hole Caught in a Post-Meal Nap

title: NASA’s ‘A Universe of Sound’ unveils space’s hidden music - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA’s “A Universe of Sound” transforms space data into mesmerising sonifications, making the cosmos accessible through sound.

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

NASA recently launched a new project called “A Universe of Sound” that turns space data into sounds. The open data conversion to sonifications, representations of data through sound, makes it possible for both blind, low-vision, and sighted users to explore space in a new way.

  • The project is led by the Chandra X-ray Observatory and Universe of Learning programs.
  • It is based on open science principles to improve accessibility and transparency.
  • The team enhances sound with data from multiple observatories like Hubble and JWST.
  • The project involves collaboration with scientists and musicians to create engaging sounds.
“I want everybody to have the same type of access to this data that I do as a scientist.” - Dr. Kimberly Arcand

This initiative connects science, arts, and education and is available to explore via NASA+ documentary and the Universe of Sound website.
newTitle: NASA’s ‘A Universe of Sound’ unveils space’s hidden music

title: Nasa discovers 'tipped-over' black hole rotating in 'unusual' direction - The Times of India
summary:
NASA Discovers Unusually Rotating Black Hole in Galaxy NGC 5084

Publication Date: Wednesday
Source: The Astrophysical Journal

Nasa researchers have discovered a black hole in galaxy NGC 5084 rotating at an unexpected angle, tipped over relative to its surrounding galaxy. This discovery was made using a new image analysis method called Selective Amplification of Ultra Noisy Astronomical Signal (SAUNAS).

  • The black hole was hidden in old data of galaxy NGC 5084, previously studied for years.
  • Researchers identified four plumes of hot, charged gas associated with the black hole.
  • There is a dusty inner disk orbiting the galaxy’s core at a 90-degree angle to the galaxy’s rotation.
  • Advanced image analysis methods were developed at NASA’s Ames Research Center.
“Detecting two pairs of X-ray plumes in one galaxy is exceptional,” said Pamela Marcum, an Ames astrophysicist.

This unusual orientation and structure might be attributed to major cosmic events such as galaxy collisions or superheated gas chimneys breaking through the galactic plane.
newTitle: NASA Discovers Unusually Rotating Black Hole in Galaxy NGC 5084

title: Pause work on ‘mirror life’, recommends panel of international experts - Chemistry World
The Protein Problem: The Unsolved Mystery of AI Drug Dev - Medscape
summary:
The Protein Problem: The Unsolved Mystery of AI Drug Development

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Unknown

The article explores the current limitations in using AI, particularly models like AlphaFold, for drug discovery despite their advancements in predicting protein structures.

  • AlphaFold has revolutionized the prediction of protein structures, yet drug discovery remains challenging.
  • Proteins' dynamic nature complicates the design of drugs that effectively bind to their target mutations.
  • Scientists are combining AI with physics-based methods to improve drug-target interactions.
  • Models like PIONEER help understand protein interactions across the entire human interactome.
  • AI tools such as GPT-4 are enhancing predictions of protein structures and mutation effects.
“The changing landscape of shapes that a protein can take prevents the drug from binding.” - Gabriel Monteiro da Silva

Despite the progress, there remains a significant gap in achieving sufficient accuracy in drug design solely through AI-driven methods.
newTitle: The Protein Problem: The Unsolved Mystery of AI Drug Development

title: See ‘Shooting Stars’ On The Solstice As Ursid Meteor Shower Peaks This Weekend - Forbes
summary:
See ‘Shooting Stars’ On The Solstice As Ursid Meteor Shower Peaks This Weekend

Date: December 21, 2024
Source: Forbes

The Ursid meteor shower is set to peak on December 21, coinciding with the winter solstice. While it yields about 10 shooting stars per hour, it might surprise observers with occasional bursts of activity.

Key Points

  • The Ursid meteor shower occurs annually from December 13-24, with the best viewing on December 21-22 in 2024.
  • Caused by dust from Comet 8P/Tuttle, Ursids are often brighter than other meteor showers.
  • Best seen from the Northern Hemisphere, particularly near the Ursa Minor constellation.

Notable Quotes or Statistics

“About 5-10 Ursids per hour can be seen around the peak, with occasional outbursts producing over 25 per hour.”

Conclusion

For optimal viewing of the Ursid meteor shower, find a dark area away from light pollution, and enjoy the celestial show.
newTitle: See ‘Shooting Stars’ On The Solstice As Ursid Meteor Shower Peaks This Weekend

title: Binary Star System D9 Found Orbiting Sagittarius A* Near Milky Way’s Core - Gadgets 360
Japan's ispace to land Hakuto-R 2 spacecraft on Moon's Sea of Cold, take a long lunar route - India Today
summary:
Japan's ispace to land spacecraft on Moon's Sea of Cold, take a long lunar route

Published On: Dec 19, 2024 | Source: India Today

Ispace, a Tokyo-based lunar exploration company, has announced its second lunar mission targeting a soft landing on the Moon's Sea of Cold.

  • The six-day launch window opens in mid-January 2025.
  • The mission will deploy a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket.
  • The lunar lander will take several months to reach the Moon using a low-energy trajectory.
  • Mission 2 aims to execute a lunar flyby and soft landing, utilizing backup sites for mission flexibility.
“Mission 2 represents our continued commitment to the lunar economy,” said Takeshi Hakamada, Founder & CEO of ispace.

This mission underlines the synergy between private space companies and international agencies, enhancing the development of a robust lunar economy.
newTitle: Japan's ispace to land spacecraft on Moon's Sea of Cold, take a long lunar route

title: NASA Warns Of Two Massive Asteroids Set For Close Encounter With Earth On THIS Date, Check Time, Speed And Dis - Times Now
summary:
NASA Warns Of Two Massive Asteroids Set For Close Encounter With Earth

Date: December 21, 2024 | Source: Times Now

NASA is keeping a close watch on two house-sized asteroids, 2024 XQ4 and 2024 XN15, which will make their closest approaches to Earth on December 21, 2024. NASA confirms that they pose no threat to our planet.

  • Asteroid 2024 XQ4 has a diameter of 50 feet and will pass within 1,060,000 kilometers of Earth at 47,634 km/h at 3:03 PM IST.
  • Asteroid 2024 XN15 is approximately 60 feet in diameter, passing at a distance of 3,780,000 kilometers at 35,051 km/h, closest at 2:38 PM IST.
  • Both asteroids do not classify as Potentially Hazardous Objects according to NASA's criteria.
  • NASA utilizes a network of telescopes for tracking Near-Earth Objects to assess their trajectories and risks.
“Neither of these asteroids classifies as a Potentially Hazardous Object (PHO).”

This monitoring highlights the effectiveness of NASA's tracking systems, ensuring public safety while observing celestial phenomena.
newTitle: NASA Warns Of Two Massive Asteroids Set For Close Encounter With Earth

title: Nasa unveils image of wreath-like cluster, symbolising life, death, and rebirth of stars - The Times of India
summary:
NASA Unveils Wreath-Like Star Cluster Image Symbolizing Stellar Life Cycles

Publication Date: Tuesday | Source: Times of India

Nasa has released a captivating image of the NGC 602 star cluster, which resembles a holiday wreath, representing the cycle of life and death of stars. Captured using the James Webb Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory, it reveals a vibrant depiction of stellar formation.

  • The NGC 602 cluster is about 200,000 light-years from Earth in the Small Magellanic Cloud.
  • The image showcases a ring-shaped formation of dust clouds in green, yellow, blue, and orange hues.
  • X-ray data from Chandra reveals young, massive stars that illuminate the dust and emit high-energy light.
  • The cluster's stars contain fewer heavy elements, resembling conditions from billions of years ago.
Nasa explains that the X-rays come from winds generated by the young, massive stars scattered across the cluster.

This image offers a glimpse into the stellar lifecycle and provides scientists with valuable insights into the early universe.
newTitle: NASA Unveils Wreath-Like Star Cluster Image Symbolizing Stellar Life Cycles

title: 5 mesmerising space findings by NASA Hubble Space Telescope - HT Tech
summary:
5 Mesmerizing Space Findings by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: December 3, 2024 | Source: HT TECH

The article discusses five significant findings made by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope over its more than three decades of operation, showcasing breathtaking images of deep space.

  • The Hubble Space Telescope has provided a unique view of galaxies and cosmic phenomena.
  • Notable discoveries include the spiral galaxy IC 3225 and UGC 10043, located 150 million light-years away.
  • Hubble has captured images of galaxy M90, revealing its structure and composition.
  • The telescope continues to shed light on countless cosmic mysteries.
  • Images from Hubble are vital for ongoing astronomical research and education.
This is Hubble’s enduring legacy: to inspire and illuminate the wonders of the universe.

The findings highlight the continued importance of the Hubble Space Telescope in expanding our understanding of the universe.
newTitle: 5 Mesmerizing Space Findings by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope
